Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: ~4 hours
5 houirs
3 for assignments, 7-8 on midterm/final
Maybe 3 for the weekly write-up (research+actually writing it). Midterm and final assignments took a good deal longer.
4-6 hours on average.
12 h / week
3h
2hours
2-3 hrs
4 hours per week
Great self exploration of the topics outside of class through the write-ups.

The lectures were very engaging and critical thinking was highly encouraged. The assignments were helpful as topics could be chosen to relate to each student's interests, and the instructor's feedback was very thorough.
Extremely interesting tying physiology to public health. Ver relevant to the major porblems we face today.
The course is good but speed is a little bit too fast.

Strengths: 
- Including questions for discussion with other students in class helped me engage with the material more and made it easier to understand how to apply concepts we'd just learned.
- The weekly assignments allowed me to explore topics that I was actually interested in but was never given an opportunity to write about in previous courses.

Weaknesses:
- A lot of material is covered in the two-hour lecture (understandable given the breadth of the course). It can be a little exhausting and difficult to concentrate near the end of the lecture, which is typically when the TF starts lecturing. It might be nice to include a short stretch break in the middle of class, especially given that this is a Physiology course where we encourage physical activity so much.

This is a good course! I like that we were able to focus the weekly assignments on areas of interest to us. The major weakness is that what we learn in class doesn't match up with the content of the assignments and didn't really come together until the exams.

Really great course. Physiology is something I have always found interesting, and we hit all of the key points. Each week is for a different system, and sometimes we're lucky to spend 2 weeks on a single system (liver, cardiovascular). My favorite part about the course was the opportunity to write about any topic you want for the weekly write-up. There were students from various departments in the course, so you can really tie in your own interests with the system we studied. This made the assignments a ton of fun for me, as it gave me the opportunity to 1) learn more about the physiology relevant to my interests and 2) dive deeper to explore the nuances of my topic of interest.
It's very helpful for students begin learning academic writing. Each week we need to submit a write-up with different topic which trained our ability of searching materials and writing.

The strengths of the course were the professor and TF's in-depth knowledge, the richness of the slides and readings, and the open, inviting interactions between professor and student via the weekly reflections.  The only weakness was the sometimes vague phrasing of questions on the midterm and final (might be helpful to have the TF or another pair of eyes read through for clarity to students before posting).
Very good class. It is helpful if you are coming in with some physiology background.
Loved this course but lots of work.
very very useful
This is a fantastic course, honestly no improvements or suggestions. I learned a lot, great pace, wonderfully curated material!
I appreciated the weekly write up and structure of the course was not too burdensome but allowed you to explore your own interests.

This is an accessible physiology class with direct practical applications, doable for people with no physiology background or people that need a refresher. It was very interactive, which is always great. The instructor is passionate, very accessible, and truly wants her students to learn. The weekly write ups kept us engaged, but they were very broad so didn't always feel directly related or pertinent to the class. The other sometimes difficult thing is that the slides often seem disorganized and incomplete - more like a stream of consciousness rather than organized information. It made it pretty difficult to study with them.

Strengths: very informative, covered all the systems 
Weaknesses: the exams were very difficult

Loved the course. We covered the major systems, all while tying together the content and presenting an epi/public health perspective. There was a lot of ground to cover but I think Yeckel did a great job doing this. One opportunity for improvement would be to have a bit more structure in the group activities. They were mostly fun but we could have gotten more out of them if they were like informal case presentations or something.

The course was really interesting and my first physiology class so I am really happy to have gotten that foundation. It was very comprehensive and detailed without losing the context of public health.

Strengths: you learn so much about physiology from both a biological and public health standpoint in just one semester. You learn to think critically about the material and the class is very engaging.

Weaknesses: it would've been nicer if the slides had more detail; Catherine is incredibly knowledgeable but the material she presented sometimes either deviated from the slides or weren't included in the slides at all, so preparing for the write-ups and studying for exams were often challenging.

This was an EXCELLENT class! Professor Yeckel gave an amazing overview of major body systems, and balanced detail with larger public health ramifications (for example, we learned both about the microscopic structures of the kidney and about how our current sedentary lifestyle can interfere with function and lead to CKD.) The class included dynamic, thought-provoking questions/scenarios to get us critically thinking about how these body systems work and what their vulnerabilities are. The lectures were fascinating and very easy to pay attention to -- I looked forward to attending every week.

If you are at all interested in medicine, or even if you just have an extra open class and want something interesting, you should take this class!

The course was amazing. In terms of knowledge gained, I think this course taught me the most over the whole semester than any other one I've taken here. You are introduced to topics in a way that truly engage you, and give you a deep understanding of the material. Only thing I would improve is the structure of the slides, sometimes the organization just got a little tough to read. Loved the slides themselves though!
Great at answering questions and presenting the information in a easy manner.
The instructor was very involved in student development and engagement and highly encouraged course participation.
Very engaging, prepared, really excites me to learn more material. I truly do not have ways to improve teaching.
Very passionate and responsive instructor.

Strengths:
- Has a wide range of knowledge on so many public health issues related to physiology and does an amazing job at explaining complex topics to students who may have no background in the subject matter.
- Incredibly positive and full of energy. You can tell that she is passionate and enjoys the material she teaches and does a great job at engaging students with the material.
- Her comments on weekly assignments have helped me improve my public health communication skills as the weeks have gone on.

Weaknesses:
- None. Anyone who has the opportunity to take a class with Dr. Yeckel or at least talk to her outside of class is incredibly lucky and privileged.
She is extremely kind and passionate about the subject material. Very receptive to student questions and gave good feedback on assignments.

Dr. Yeckel is incredibly passionate and enthusiastic about the material. You could tell how fascinated she is by the field during lectures, and she designed a really interesting discussion component in the course. She was so approachable as well, and she is overall very kind and personable. I enjoyed her leading of the course very much.

Prof. Yeckel is very patient. Every question will be answered with lots of details. Moreover, she taught me to think about the physiology knowledge not only just limited in each systems, but also compare the knowledge in different systems. That's very help for better understanding body physiology.

Prof. Yeckel is extremely knowledgeable, personable, and interested in students' learning about topics at the intersection of physiology and public health.  She is engaging throughout her lectures and helps you to learn how to better apply clinical and basic science knowledge at a large, population scale.
Wonderful! Really cares about her students!
Wonderful professor who knows her stuff!
very very good instructor

Gives amazing feedback, cares about what kind of public health professionals her students will be, and encourages people to think critically.  I am so grateful to have had the opportunity to work with her.
Dr. Yeckel is the best professor I have had a YSPH. Dr. Yeckel is so knowledgeable about almost every topic related to the course and takes the energy to specialize feedback towards your interests.

Catherine is a gem of a human. She is the most enthusiastic professor I've ever experienced; it's very clear that this subject is her absolute passion. This enthusiasm can definitely rub off, and it makes you want to work to make sure you don't disappoint her. It can also sometimes mean that lectures can get a little tangential and sometimes a little scattered. She is a wonderful person who cares about her students, understand that life happens, and is always accessible. Her feedback on the write ups and exams was thorough and enthusiastic.

Strengths: Very kind and understanding. 
Weaknesses: would like a break at the half way point of class- would allow students to refocus.
Great. Very helpful and responsive outside of class.

Professor Yeckel is a truly phenomenal professor. She is capable of explaining complex processes in simple maters. I really appreciate the variety of assignments since it allowed for demonstrating knowledge in different contexts. Professor Yeckel is really understanding and provides fantastic feedback - so detailed and clarifying where there was confusion on a concept.
Great instructor
Catherine is so passionate about this class and is incredibly knowledgeable. She also cares very deeply about us as students both in and out of the classroom. So wonderful!

What an awesome professor! Professor Yeckel was extremely knowledgeable, enthusiastic, clear, and dynamic. The readings were relevant to class, and the lectures were wonderful. I looked forward to lecture every week, and had zero trouble staying engaged in the material. She gave clear, timely feedback on our weekly reading responses, asked thought provoking questions that testing our knowledge of organ systems. She was very kind and helpful during office hours. Overall, I really think Professor Yeckel is a great teacher, and I very much hope she continues to teach this course. Thank you!

Fantastic! Always brought energy and positivity, and truly wanted to engage with her students. Feedback was always critical but in the most kind and helpful ways. Her passion for her work and research was so evident, which was very inspiring.
I would recommend this course. It's a great physiology course and makes you think critically through self guided work as opposed to instructor assigned topics.
This course offers a good summary for physiology in particular body systems, and it allows students to engage with materials relevant to their own particular research interests.

Most interesting course I took at YSPH. I would absolutely recommend it. What you learn in this course not only changes your understanding of physiology in the context of public health, but changes your understanding about yourself and your community.
good but difficult

Even if you have no background in physiology and don't intend to study it further in the future, I would definitely recommend that you take this course. It gives a great overview of the main body systems, which is very useful when trying to study chronic or infectious diseases. Dr. Yeckel is very knowledgeable in this field and does a great job summarizing the important points that students need to know. The course doesn't involve an excessive amount of time or work, but students will have to be engaged in the material during lecture to gain the most from this class.
I would recommended it--a good overview of physiology and the assignments were good/relevant.

I would highly recommend it if you have an existing interest in physiology. The class is pretty heavy on the science, so if you like that, this is a great course for you. The autonomy in the write-ups is a big plus, so that gives you an opportunity to learn more about your own interests as well as to put the lecture material in a different context.
A good course for improving academic writing and critical thinking.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking to learn more about human physiology.  Each week explores a different body system or organ, and you'll have autonomy to design your own deep dive into a related topic of interest in the weekly reflections.  The professor is extremely knowledgeable, very approachable, and fair in the grading of the reflections, midterm, and final.  I don't know why this isn't a requirement for everyone graduating from YSPH -- physiology is the basis of health and, therefore, public health!
Yes.
I would strongly recommend this course!
I would definitely recommend this course especially if you are considering gaining any type of clinical based degree following YSPH

A fun course, a good application of physiology to practical, public health issues. Good for people with and without physiology experience. It does demand a chunk of your time, as there are weekly write ups that require research (only a page long, though). It's important to take good notes in class, because the slides are sometimes disorganized and don't include everything that was talked about in class, and are not always the most helpful when studying. The exams need critical thinking, but Catherine is great about being flexible as long as you justify your answer. She's also a wonderful professor, who genuinely cares about her students, is flexible if things come up for you, and crazy enthusiastic about what she teaches
I would recommend this course for other students who are interested in biological determinants of health and medicine.
Highly recommend.
Great introduction to physiology with a special focus on public health affairs. I would strongly suggest it to any student!
Highly recommend this class to any student, particularly those with a background in biology!
It's a wonderful class! Exciting, dynamic lectures, really interesting material, and a reasonable course load. Professor Yeckel is amazing. You should take this class!

I would recommend this course! If you are remotely interested in physiology at all it is a must. It is a perfect combination of physiology and public health, and it will prepare anyone who takes it to be a prepared public health practitioner.
